linkTarget.anchoringText: In the Northeast natural gas market, prices are now at a discount to soak up production and ward off supply from other producing regions. Pricing points in the Northeast now trade at a discount to the benchmark Henry Hub prices (Figure 1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Select Pricing Points in the Northeast: Dominion South and TCO Pool Basis Differentials. Source: CME Group 2015 .

formatted-caption.caption-text: Select Pricing Points in the Northeast: Dominion South and TCO Pool Basis Differentials. Source: CME Group 2015 .

linkTarget.bib: CME Group. 2015. Energy Products Home (6 July 2015), http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/energy/ #naturalGas (accessed 6 July 2015).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Nine pipeline projects came into service in 2014 totalling 3.4 Bcf/d of capacity. Another 35 pipeline projects, totaling 29.8 Bcf/d of capacity, are planned and slated to start service between 2015 and 2018 with the goal of providing the much-needed new takeaway capacity for Northeast producers to access demand markets outside the Northeast (Figure 2).

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Dry Gas Takeaway Capacity Additions from the Northeast by Destination (Left Axis). Cumulative Additional Takeaway Capacity from the Northeast (Right Axis). Source: Range Resources 2015 .

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dry Gas Takeaway Capacity Additions from the Northeast by Destination (Left Axis). Cumulative Additional Takeaway Capacity from the Northeast (Right Axis). Source: Range Resources 2015 .

linkTarget.bib: Range Resources. 2015. Company Presentations (17 June 2015),http://phx.corporate-ir.net/phoenix.zhtml?c_101196&p_irol-presentations (accessed 3 July 2015).

linkTarget.anchoringText: In this paper, type curves are established for geographic breakouts of the Marcellus and Utica, each consisting of four separate production areas. The Marcellus is divided into West Virginia, West Pennsylvania, North Pennsylvania, and South Pennsylvania. The Utica is divided into Dry Gas, Lean Condensate, Rich Condensate, and Oily. The production areas fall within the states of Pennsylvania, West Virginia, and Ohio. The geographic locations of the breakouts are provided in Figure 3.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Marcellus and Utica Production Areas

formatted-caption.caption-text: Marcellus and Utica Production Areas

linkTarget.anchoringText: The prominent gas-producing areas used for comparison are the Fayetteville, Haynesville, Ft. Worth, Woodford, Piceance, Green River-Overthrust, and the Cana Woodford. In the Permian, the Midland and Delaware basins are considered. The Eagleville and Briscoe Ranch are the areas evaluated in the Eagle Ford. A geographical representation of these areas is provided in Figure 4.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Producing Areas Considered in Analysis.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Producing Areas Considered in Analysis.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The natural gas type curves are visualized in Figure 5 and the crude oil type curves in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Marcellus Natural Gas Type Curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Marcellus Natural Gas Type Curves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The natural gas type curves are visualized in Figure 5 and the crude oil type curves in Figure 6.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Marcellus Oil Type Curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Marcellus Oil Type Curves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The natural gas type curves are visualized in Figure 7 and the crude oil type curves in Figure 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Utica Natural Gas Type Curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Utica Natural Gas Type Curves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The natural gas type curves are visualized in Figure 7 and the crude oil type curves in Figure 8.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Utica Oil Type Curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Utica Oil Type Curves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The natural gas type curves for the areas within the Permian and Eagle Ford are visualized in Figure 9. The natural gas type curves for the remaining areas are shown in Figure 10. The crude oil type curves for these areas are shown in Figure 1.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: Permian and Eagle Ford Type Curves.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Permian and Eagle Ford Type Curves.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The natural gas type curves for the remaining areas are shown in Figure 10. The crude oil type curves for these areas are shown in Figure 1. Due to the low IP rates and steep declines for many of the gas plays, the Green River-Overthrust, Piceance, Woodford, and Ft. Worth crude oil type curves have been omitted from Figure 10.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Natural Gas Type Curves for Other Considered Areas.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Natural Gas Type Curves for Other Considered Areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Crude Oil Type Curves for Other Considered Areas.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crude Oil Type Curves for Other Considered Areas.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Marcellus and Utica will realize growth in natural gas, crude oil, and NGLs moving forward. Gross natural gas production will reach 27.1 Bcf/d by 2020 (Figure 12). The bulk of gross natural gas production will come from the Marcellus, particularly the West Pennsylvania and West Virginia production areas.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Gross Natural Gas Production by Area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gross Natural Gas Production by Area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Associated crude oil production will continue to grow as drilling continues in the Northeast. The production is on track to reach almost 200 MBbl/d by 2020 (Figure 13). The majority of this crude oil can be classified as condensate. Refineries in the region will struggle to accommodate the growing volumes of light crude oil, as they are particularly tooled for heavier crude oil from Canada.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Crude Oil Production Forecast.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Crude Oil Production Forecast.

linkTarget.anchoringText: NGL production growth will reach just shy of 550 MBbl/d by 2020 (Figure 14). This growth will require additional processing capacity in the Northeast and lead to more NGL pipelines being built to the coasts. The same forecast is also provided by product in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: NGL Production by Area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: NGL Production by Area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: NGL production growth will reach just shy of 550 MBbl/d by 2020 (Figure 14). This growth will require additional processing capacity in the Northeast and lead to more NGL pipelines being built to the coasts. The same forecast is also provided by product in Figure 15.

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: NGL Production by Product.

formatted-caption.caption-text: NGL Production by Product.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Dry Natural Gas Production by Area.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Dry Natural Gas Production by Area.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Marcellus and Utica will continue to grow and contribute to the production of natural gas in the US. This is evident from the breakeven natural gas prices shown in Figures 17–20. These figures portray the necessary natural gas price to achieve different levels of return (WACC) at various crude oil prices. West Virginia, West Pennsylvania, and North Pennsylvania have the lowest breakeven natural gas prices of any play outside of the production areas that are producing gas at an associated capacity.

image-wrap.label: Figure 17
image-wrap.caption: Breakeven Gas Prices at Various Crude Oil Prices. WACC of 0%.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Breakeven Gas Prices at Various Crude Oil Prices. WACC of 0%.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The Marcellus and Utica will continue to grow and contribute to the production of natural gas in the US. This is evident from the breakeven natural gas prices shown in Figures 17–20. These figures portray the necessary natural gas price to achieve different levels of return (WACC) at various crude oil prices. West Virginia, West Pennsylvania, and North Pennsylvania have the lowest breakeven natural gas prices of any play outside of the production areas that are producing gas at an associated capacity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: It boasts superior economics to all but the best of the oil-producing plays that can, depending on the price of crude oil, count natural gas as associated production in terms of their economics. Appendix A shows the breakeven crude oil prices for various basins considered in the analysis at various natural gas prices. Regardless of natural gas and crude oil price combinations, the Marcellus will continue to be at the top of the stack in terms of superior IRRs (Figures 21–27).

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: IRR at Various Crude Oil Prices. Gas Price of $2.00/MMBtu.

formatted-caption.caption-text: IRR at Various Crude Oil Prices. Gas Price of $2.00/MMBtu.
